LEAVE RULES FOR THE INDIAN STAFF CORPS.

(Published in Army Circulars, India, 16 April, 1886.)

1. An officer may be granted,— Privilege Leave under such regulations as may from time to time be in force.

Leave out of India, for no longer period than one year, capable of extension to two years' absence from duty, on the following pay:—

After appointment to the Staff Corps £200 a year.

After the commencement of the 5th year's service for pension 250

Ditto, ditto, 15th ditto, ditto 300

Ditto, ditto, 20th ditto, ditto 450

Ditto, ditto, 25th ditto, ditto 600

Ditto, ditto, 30th ditto, ditto 700

Leave in India, but for the period of one year only on full military pay and half the Staff salary of appointment.

2. No extension of leave involving absence from duty for more than two years, whether taken in or out of India, can be granted except on specially urgent grounds and without pay.

3. An officer, unable on account of the state of his health to return to duty within the maximum period of two years' absence, will, unless he is under Rule 2 specially granted an extension of leave without pay, be placed on temporary half pay or the retired list, as the circumstances of the case may seem to require.

An officer will also be liable to be placed on half pay or the retired list should his health require an undue amount of leave, whether in or out of India. This power will be exercised at the instance of the Government of his own Presidency should the officer be in India, or, should he be at home, by the Secretary of State in Council.

4. All leave in or out of India will count as service for pension.

5. Leave, whether it is leave in India or leave out of India, will not involve forfeiture of appointment, and may be granted at any time, but solely at the discretion of the Commanders-in-Chief of the several armies for officers serving directly under their orders, and by the Governor-General in Council or the Governors in Council for officers of Civil departments of the Army, or of Corps not under the direct orders of a Commander-in-Chief.

6. An officer on leave, whether in India or out of India, will be required to rejoin at once on being recalled to duty, unless certified by a Medical Board as unfit to do so.

7. The above Rules shall apply to— Officers whose admission to the Staff Corps shall bear date subsequent to the 30th June, 1886.

Officers of the Staff Corps, including probationers, or of the Cavalry and Infantry List, of the Indian Army, in military employment, who may elect them within twelve months of that date. Officers applying for leave of any kind within that period must elect on making their application. Officers already on leave at date of promulgation must elect at once, and the new Rules will apply to them from the date on which their notification of acceptance shall be received at either army headquarters or by the Government of India, or by the Local
Governments, or at the India Office at home, as the case may be.

Officers in Civil employ on that date, subsequently reverting to military duty, who may elect them within six months from the date of being replaced at the disposal of the Military Department, and such officers who may be on leave when so replaced must make their election at once. Those taking leave within the six months must make their election before going on leave.

They shall not apply to—

Officers in permanent Civil employ.

Officers commanding divisions, districts, or brigades, or holding other appointments under special regulations as to leave of absence, who will continue subject to such regulations.

8. Officers who, under Rule 7, elect to come under them will count all previous leave as service for pension. The position of those who do not so elect will remain unchanged.

9. The Secretary of State in Council reserves the right of making any change in the foregoing regulations which circumstances may require.

Indian Medical Service.

The above Rules apply equally to officers of the Indian Medical Service in military employ, with the following modification in regard to the rates of pay whilst on leave out of India:—

After arrival in India £200 a year.

After the commencement of the

5th year's service for pension 250

Ditto, ditto, 10th ditto 300

Ditto, ditto, 15th ditto 400

Ditto, ditto, 20th ditto 450

Ditto, ditto, 25th ditto 500

The Rules will apply to all Medical Officers admitted to the Service after the 30th June, 1886, and to officers who may elect them under the provisions of Rule 7.

(India Army Circulars, June, 1887, Clause 90.)

With reference to Rule VII. and Clause 2 of Rule IX. of the Leave Rules for the Staff Corps published in Clause 51, India Army Circulars, 1886, it is notified that any officer in military employment (including Medical officers), whose election of Leave Rules shall not have been received by the 1st July, 1887, will be held to have finally declined those Rules.

DECISIONS ON THE LEAVE RULES FOR THE STAFF CORPS.

(Published in India Army Circulars,* subsequently to the promulgation of the Rules.)

1. Officers in permanent civil employment, while they continue in such employment, are not affected by these Rules; but if desirous of retiring on pension direct from such employment, they will, whether on duty or on Furlough, be given the benefit of the Rule which allows all previous leave to count as service for pension.

It is, however, to be clearly understood that no officer in civil employment will be allowed to place himself out of employment for the purpose of taking leave under these Rules, or for any purpose but immediate retirement.

2. There is no subsidiary leave under these Rules. Leave under them commences from the date of an officer's being struck off duty, and terminates on the date he rejoins his regiment or appointment, the only exception being in case of leave out of India recommended by a Medical Board, when the period granted is held to commence from the date of the officer's quitting India, and to terminate on, and include, the date previous to that of his rejoining his regiment or appointment. But under any circumstances the absence from duty, which is restricted to two years with pay (Rule 2), will reckon from the date of an officer being struck off duty.

3. When leave "in and out of India" is granted to an officer on medical certificate in continuation of leave "in India," the former will reckon from the date of termination of the latter, subject to the limit of two years' absence from duty.

4. The term "date of being struck off duty" is intended to mean the date following the day an officer is relieved of his duties. But in the case of an officer obliged to leave his station to appear before a Medical Board at another station, the date of being "struck off duty" will mean the date he is permitted to quit the station where he is examined and invalided.

Up to date of leaving India, and from date of return to India to date of rejoining regiment or appointment, officers granted leave out of India under these Rules will receive Indian pay and half staff salary, provided in any case the two years' absence from duty mentioned in Rule 2 (p. lxxxi.) is not exceeded.

5. The Indian Pension Regulations are unaffected by these Leave Rules, except that all leave from date of commencement of service for pension will, under them, be allowed to count as service for pension.

6. Time passed at Addiscombe after the attainment of the age of 16 years will reckon as service for pension in calculating the rates of pay under Rule I.

7. The period o service for pension in Rule I. of the Leave Rules will entitle an officer tak-

---

* I. A. C. Clauses 113 and 197 of 1886, 37, 105, and 106 of 1887, 78 of 1888, 33, 44, & 105 of 1889.
ing leave to the pay fixed for such periods of service, without any limitation based on the Rule* which prevents an officer from retiring on the pension fixed for a particular period of service, unless he has served half of that service in the Staff Corps.

8. The provisions of the Rules with regard to duration of leave do not apply to probationers for the Staff Corps.

9. The limit of two years laid down for leave will not apply to time spent at the Staff College, which counts as duty.

10. Officers recalled from leave granted under these rules will be given free passage to India, or not, according to the Transport Regulations in force at the time.

11. Advances of pay to officers proceeding on and returning from leave out of India will be granted as heretofore.

12. Extensions of leave, except on medical certificate or in special or urgent cases in which the Secretary of State decides according to circumstances, cannot be granted without the assent of the proper authorities in India as defined in Rule V.

13. Extensions of leave beyond one year under the new rules are not claimable in any way as a right, but are admissible only at the discretion of the proper authority, and then on special and urgent grounds.

14. An officer subject to these rules, on promotion to Major-General will not be granted leave under them, but, if permitted to reside in England or elsewhere out of India, will be restricted to the English pay of his rank.

15. Officers subject to these Rules who are in the following categories, and who entered the Indian Army or Staff Corps before the 1st July, 1881, may elect to reside out of India on the allowances admissible under those Rules until succession to the Colonel's allowance or promotion to Major-General, whichever may happen first; or to remain in India on the unemployed Indian pay and allowances of their rank if unemployed.

(a.) Officers vacating regimental commands, G.G.O. 209 of remaining in the service for 1882, para. 7. the attainment of the highest retirement pension, or the Colonel's allowance.

(b.) Officers over 55 years of age, who may be required under the Rules G.G.O. 192 of to vacate Staff, Departmental 1883. or Civil appointments, and for whom other suitable employment cannot be found.

(c.) Officers of the Commissariat, Military G.G.O.432 of1884, Accounts, and Judge Advocate-General's Departments, Clause IV. (iii.) who vacate their appointments on attaining to 52 years of age.

(d.) Officers who on the 8th August, 1884, G.G.O. 432 of 1884, Clause VII. were holding appointments of unlimited tenure to which they were appointed before the 1st January, 1884, and who vacate their appointments on completing seven years' tenure from date of appointment or such further extension as may be granted to enable them to complete 32 years' service for pension, not exceeding nine years in all.

(e.) Squadron or Wing Commanders who G.G.O.310 of1885 vacate their appointments on attaining 52 years of age.

(f.) Colonels who entered the Staff Corps Secretary of after the 12th September, State's despatch 1886, and before the 1st July, No. 6, dated 6th General List, after transfer to Jan., 1887. the Supernumerary List.

The limit of absence from duty imposed by the new Leave Rules will not be held applicable to these officers.

16. Officers who may have entered civil employment after the 30th June, 1886, and before the 1st July, 1887, without having elected the Leave Rules for the Staff Corps, will be entitled, on reverting to military duty, to elect them under the conditions laid down in the third clause of Rule VII.

17. Officers who may have entered civil employment after the 30th June, 1886, having previously elected the Leave Rules for the Staff Corps, and officers who may have entered the Staff Corps under those Rules and subsequently taken civil employment, will be absolutely under the leave rules contained in the Civil Service Regulations, so long as they remain in permanent civil employment, but on reverting to military duty within ten years of their entry into civil employment, as allowed under G.G.O. No. 135 of 1884, they will again come under the Leave Rules for the Staff Corps.

19. Officers struck off the effective list of the army under the provisions of G.G.O. No. 135 of 1884, after ten years' absence from military duty, cannot elect or revert to the Leave Rules for the Staff Corps, except for the purpose of immediate retirement, with the advantage of counting all leave as service for pension, as provided for in Clause 113, India Army Circulars 1886 (para. 1, above).

(India Army Circulars, March, 1887, Clause 33.)

All officers in military employ, irrespective of rank or the Furlough or Leave Regulations to which they may be subject, who require an extension on private affairs of their Furlough or leave out of India, must obtain the previous assent of the authorities in India under whom they may be serving, to apply for such extension.

This permission, when obtained, must be attached to their application to the India Office for the required extension.

Officers proceeding on Furlough to Europe may, if they desire it, receive an advance equivalent to three months' Furlough pay. Officers returning from Furlough or from temporary half-pay will similarly be granted advances of pay at the following rates, on obtaining permission to return:

For a Subaltern ... £65
For all higher ranks ... £100

No advance, however, will be issued to an officer who obtains from the Fund to which he is a subscriber a loan equal to or greater than the advance authorized for his rank, and an officer who obtains from his Fund a loan less in amount than such advance will be granted only the difference between the two.

The only "next higher" rates which give any pecuniary advantage are those of £456 per annum after 24 years' service for pension, and £550 after 27, 28, or 29 years' service for pension.

10. Four extra pensions of £100 a-year each are annually granted to the senior officers of the Indian Medical Service in the proportion of two for the Bengal, and one each for the Madras and Bombay Presidencies. Officers admitted to the service after August, 1889, are not eligible for these pensions. They are offered yearly in rotation to Surgeons-Major-General, Surgeon-Colonels, and to all Brigade-Surgeon-Lieut.-Colonels; but under no circumstances is the extra pension given to a Surgeon-Major-General or Surgeon-Colonel until he has completed three years' actual service in the grade, excluding all leave except Privilege Leave, and then only when from failing health or other unforeseen causes he may be unable to complete his full tour of service. Applications for these pensions must be made to the Surgeons-Major-General with the Government of India, Madras, and Bombay respectively, on or before the 1st April in each year. (See Clause 91 of India Army Circulars, 1886.)

HALF PAY.

10. If he has not served 14 years altogether, his case will be specially considered.

11. Retirement is compulsory at the age of 55 years.

12. All Warrant Officers on the establishment on 16th September, 1881, will be allowed the option of electing the old or the new scale of pensions at any time previous to retirement.

13. Pension, according to the present scale and conditions, is admissible to the widow of a Warrant Officer who may die, either while in the service or on the Pension establishment, provided, in the latter case, that she married the deceased Warrant Officer previous to his retiring from the army or being invalided.

REGULATIONS FOR THE COMMUTATION OF PENSIONS OF OFFICERS OF THE INDIAN SERVICE.

1. These Regulations shall be applicable only to officers retired on or after the 1st July, 1881.

2. An officer may be allowed to commute a portion, not exceeding one-third, of his pension, which commutation may take place on retirement, or at any time subsequent thereto.

3. An Officer in Europe desirous of commutating must make application, in writing, to the Under Secretary of State for India, stating his desire so to commute, and furnishing information as to his age, rank, and the amount of his pension.

4. If the Secretary of State for India in Council shall approve the commutation, the officer will be so informed, and his application will be forwarded to the Standing Medical Board at the India Office.

5. The Board will require the officer to give such information as to his health and habits as is usual in the case of persons proposing to assure their lives in assurance companies, and he will be required to submit himself for personal examination by the Board at the India Office.

6. An officer in India desirous of commuting must address the authorities of his Presidency. He will be required to go through similar forms, Boards, which will, when practicable, be presided over by the chief Civil Medical Administrative Officer of the Government, being formed in the Presidency towns of Calcutta, Madras, and Bombay, under orders of the respective Governments.

7. The basis of commutation, subject to an addition of years of age in the case of impaired lives, shall be the following table, the age of the officer being reckoned at the age he will attain on the birthday next succeeding the date upon which the capitalised sum will become payable:

8. The commutation having been sanctioned, the applicant will be informed, and will have the option of withdrawing his application within 30 days after receiving that notice.

9. If the applicant shall not withdraw his application within that period, the decision will be considered final, and the commutation of pension will take place absolutely.

10. In every case the capitalised sum will be payable in India, the sterling amount being converted at the official rate of exchange for the year in which the payment is made.

11. In the case of an officer in Europe, the capitalised sum will be payable at the expiration of two months, and in the case of an officer in India, at the expiration of one month from the date of the commutation being sanctioned. In each case the officer's pension will be issued in full up to the date of payment, unless any delay has been caused by the officer's own fault or that of his agents.

12. In any case in which a pensioner shall accept public employment, involving the withholding of pension, a deduction will be made from the salary payable to him equal to the amount which would have been abated from the pension if it had not been commuted, and in the event of his becoming entitled to a pension in respect of such employment, the amount of such pension granted to him shall not exceed the amount which he might have received had his pension not been so commuted.

**CONDITIONS OF TRANSFER TO TEMPORARY HALF-PAY.**

**COMMISSIONED OFFICERS.**

*(Sanctioned by Despatch of Government of India, No. 432, dated 22nd December, 1881.)*

Officers placed on temporary half-pay, at the recommendation of the Medical Board of the India Office, shall be examined by the same Board as to their fitness to return to duty every two years, and if still reported unfit at the third examination, that is, after being six years on the temporary half-pay list, they shall be transferred to the retired list on permanent half-pay. An officer reported to be unfit at the commencement of the second period, i.e., after two years on half-pay, may, however, be permitted voluntarily to retire on permanent half-pay.

Officers unable to appear before the Medical Board at the stated times will be required to furnish a certificate, signed by two medical men, as to their inability. An officer who is continuously unable to appear will be retired permanently after six years without further report.

Officers who, in view to being restored to the active list, may wish to appear before the Board at other times than those specified, may be permitted to do so. Officers ordered periodically to appear before the Board will receive their travelling expenses and lodging allowance on the Home scale, but those appearing at other times, at their own wish, must do so at their own expense.

**WARRANT OFFICERS.**

*(Sanctioned by Despatch to Government of India, No. 25, dated 24th January, 1884.)*

A Warrant Officer transferred to temporary half-pay may be permitted to remain on half-pay till his total continuous absence from duty, on Furlough and half-pay together, amounts to four years. If then still unfit to return to duty, he must be pensioned on the rate of pension for which he had qualified at the time of being placed on half-pay.

No period spent on half-pay will count as service for Indian pension, nor will a Warrant Officer be eligible for promotion while he is on half-pay. A Warrant Officer replaced on the effective list, on return to duty from half-pay, will be re-employed at once, being borne as a supernumerary in his grade until absorbed by the next vacancy.

Warrant Officers will be required to appear before a Medical Board at the expiration of one year on half-pay, and again, if retained on the half-pay list, at the end of the second year; and those who, in view to being restored to the effective list, may wish to appear before the Board at other times than those specified, may be permitted to do so. Warrant Officers ordered periodically to appear before the Board will be allowed, in this country, their *bona fide* travelling expenses and lodging allowance at the rates stated below, but those appearing at other times, and at their own wish, must do so at their own expense.

**Rates of Lodging Allowance.**

**VICTORIA R. I.**

Whereas we deem it expedient that officers who may enter Our Indian Staff Corps on or after the date of this Warrant and who may retire on pension, shall be liable to be recalled to service in Our Indian Forces in time of emergency:

Our Will and Pleasure is as follows:

1. An Officer who shall have entered the Indian Staff Corps subsequent to the date of this Warrant, and who may retire on pension, shall remain liable to be recalled to service in Our Indian Forces in time of emergency, in accordance with such Regulations as may from time to time be made by our Secretary of State for India in Council.
2. Officers thus recalled to service shall, during their employment on army service, exercise the authority of officers of similar rank in Our Regular Forces with respect to the troops composing Our Indian Forces, or any other part of Our Regular Forces, and shall take precedence in their rank according to the date of their former commissions.

Given at Our Court at Osborne, this ninth day of January, one thousand eight hundred and ninety-two, in the Fifty-fifth year of Our reign.

By Her Majesty's command, (Signed) Cross.

ISSUE OF FURLOUGH AND RETIRED PAY.

Military and Marine Furlough and Retired Pay is made up at the India Office to the 15th February, 15th May, 15th August, and 15th November, and is payable on the 16th of each month. The sum payable each month is approximately one-third of the quarterly sum, but in the intervening months only complete pounds are issued.

MEMORANDUM REGARDING THE GRANT OF PENSIONS FROM THE MILITARY (LATE LORD CLIVE'S) FUND.

WIDOWS' PENSIONS.

1. The widows of officers who were originally in the old Indian Service are alone eligible for this pension.

2. They will be required to sign a statutory declaration as to the amount of real and personal property possessed by their late husbands and by themselves; and no widow will be eligible for the full pension if the total of such property amounts to the following sums:—if the widow of a colonel, £4,000; a lieut.-colonel, £3,000; a major, £2,500; a captain, £2,000; a lieutenant, £1,000. Life-interests and annuities are capitalised for the purpose of calculating these limits under rules laid down by the Secretary of State in Council.

3. The rates of pension are as follow:

| Ranks                                                                 | Per dm. | Per annum |
|----------------------------------------------------------------------|---------|-----------|
| Colonel, Surgeon-Major-General and Surgeon-Colonel                   | 6 3     | 114 1 3   |
| Lieut.-Colonel, Brigade-Surgeon-Lieut.-Col. and Surgeon-Lieut.-Col.  | 5 0     | 91        |
| Major, Surgeon-Major, and Captain of 15 years' service               | 3 9     | 68        |
| Captain, Surgeon-Captain, Chaplain of 7 years' service, and Veterinary Officer of 20 years' service | 2 6     | 45 12 6   |
| Chaplain under 7 years' service                                      | 1 9     | 31 18 9   |
| Lieutenant and Veterinary Surgeon                                    | 1 3     | 22 16 3   |

Pensions at diminished rates, the amount of which will be decided by the Secretary of State in Council, will, however, be granted in certain cases in which the property possessed exceeds the above limits. A diminished pension cannot, however, be granted of a lower amount than £10. This modification of the old Rule has effect from 18 February, 1890.

4. The pension of a widow may be withheld or discontinued should her conduct be such as to render her, in the opinion of the Secretary of State, unworthy of it.

5. The pension is liable to be discontinued or reduced, if at any time after the officer's death his widow receives any accession of property or income.

6. Pensions lapse on re-marriage, and are not restored on a second widowhood.

7. Pensioners neglecting to claim the pension for three half-years will be considered as dead, and no arrears for a longer period than two years back from the date of application for admission or re-admission, as the case may be, will be allowed either to claimants or to pensioners after admission.

8. The widows of officers formerly of the Indian service, who have joined the British Army, retain their claims to pension from this fund.

9. The widows of officers who have retired from the service are not eligible to the benefits of this fund.*

10. The widows of officers who at the time of their death were pensioners on Lord Clive's Fund are entitled to the benefits of the Fund, provided they were married to their husbands prior to the latter having become pensioners on such Fund.

11. The pensions are payable quarterly, on the 1st January, 1st April, 1st July, and 1st Oct.

12. In the event of any question arising concerning the qualifications of widows claiming these pensions, the decision rests with the Secretary of State in Council.

13.—These regulations are subject to any alterations which may be decided on by the Secretary of State in Council.

ROYAL INDIAN MARINE.

All first appointments of Officers and Engineers in the Royal Indian Marine are made by the Secretary of State for India in Council.

* Except in the case of the widows of General Officers compulsorily retired under the provisions of the Royal Warrants of 31st December, 1877, 1st May, 1878, 25th June, 1881, 11th March, 1882, and 10th June, 1884.
The limits of age for appointment to the junior executive rank, that of Sub-Lieutenant, are 17 and 22 years, and no candidate will be appointed who does not possess a Board of Trade certificate as Second Mate.

An application for appointment must be made on the prescribed form, which can be procured from the India Office. It must be accompanied by the candidate's Board of Trade Certificate, and by certificates of his birth and character, which will be returned after being noted. It will be recorded, but will not be submitted for the orders of the Secretary of State until there is a vacancy.

When he is qualified, the Board of Trade Certificate, together with certificates of birth and character, should be transmitted to the Military Secretary, India Office.

A Candidate must pass an examination by the India Office Medical Board prior to appointment.

On appointment a first-class passage to Bombay will be provided, and an advance of pay not exceeding £25, recoverable in India, will be made in aid of outfit.

Pay commences from date of embarkation for India. Service for pension reckons from date of arrival in India.

As a condition of their appointment to the Royal Indian Marine, Officers will be required to subscribe, from date of arrival in India, under the Indian Military Service Family Pension Regulations, for the benefits of Family Pensions.

The names of candidates will be removed from the list on their attaining the age of 22 years.

Any further information relative to the appointment of executive officers may be obtained on application to the Military Secretary, India Office.

Information in regard to the appointment of Assistant Engineer may be obtained from the Director General of Stores, India Office.

INDIA OFFICE, 1894.

FURLOUGH AND LEAVE RULES OF THE ROYAL INDIAN MARINE.

MARINE CIRCULAR OF THE GOVERNMENT OF INDIA, NO. 16 OF 1884.

Furlough.

I.—Officers after five years' service in India or under the Government of India may receive one year's Furlough, and an additional year for each subsequent five years' service. Furlough not taken at the time it becomes due is not lost, and can, subject to these regulations, be taken later.

II.—An officer may not be absent from duty on any grounds for more than three years consecutively, nor on return from Furlough may he receive, except under Rule VII., any further Furlough until after an interval of three years.

III.—*Furlough may be spent anywhere, and, when it has been earned by length of service, counts as service for pension. Furlough taken before it is earned by length of service reckons against service for pension till paid off.

IV.—An officer on Furlough receives half the pay of his rank, or, if holding a shore appointment, half the pay of his appointment, excluding command, charge, acting, personal, or house allowance, computed according to a rate of exchange to be fixed in each year by the Secretary of State. An officer promoted while on Furlough will be entitled to a moiety of the increased pay due to that promotion.

V.—†An officer proceeding on or returning from Furlough may be granted an advance of three months' Furlough pay; and he may further‡ be granted the advance in aid of passage money specified in clause IX., if he does not obtain passage by troopship. Advances made in England will be recovered in India by monthly instalments of one-fourth of the pay drawn by the officers. Advances made in India will be noted on the last-pay certificates of officers, and no issue of Furlough pay will be made till after the sum advanced has accrued as Furlough pay.

VI.—Furlough pay may not be drawn for more than two years consecutively.

VII.—Upon certificate of a Medical Board, an officer not entitled to Furlough, who has served not less than one year in India, may be granted Furlough. Such Furlough will not count as service for pension until it has been paid off by subsequent service under the terms of Rule I. Furlough cannot be anticipated beyond two years in the aggregate, nor for a second term, unless that previously anticipated has been subsequently paid off under the terms of Rule I.

VIII.—An officer who has exhausted the Furlough obtainable under these Rules, and who may be certified by a Medical Board to be still unfit for duty, will be retired on the pension or gratuity to which he may be entitled; if not entitled to either pension or gratuity, his case will be specially considered (but see under heading "Temporary Retirement," on p. lxxxvi.).

IX.—§Marine officers not holding shore appointments of Rs. 1,000 per mensem will be eligible for the grant of non-regulation passages in troopships when such passages are available. Officers who do not obtain passages in troopships will be allowed advances‡ in aid of passage money, in addition to the advances admissible under

* As modified by Marine Circular No. 6, of 1885.
† As modified by Marine Circular No. 7, of 1886.
‡ Unless holding shore appointments of Rs. 1,000 per mensem. Such officers are ineligible for passage by troopship (cl. ix.) and are also ineligible for any advance exceeding three months' Furlough pay (Marine Circular No. 1, of 1885).
§ As modified by Marine Circular No. 31 of 1885.
Clause V., provided that no officer shall in any case draw advances exceeding three months' pay in all.

X.—Furlough, whether on private affairs or on Medical certificate, is restricted to a maximum period of one year in the first instance, and to subsequent extensions not exceeding six months at a time.

General Leave.

XI.—General Leave may be granted for any period not exceeding six months at a time, but cannot be renewed, except for very urgent reasons, till after two years have elapsed from its expiration. It may be spent anywhere, does not involve forfeiture of appointment, and counts as service for pension. It will be granted or refused entirely at the discretion of the Director of the Indian Marine. It may be granted up to a maximum limit of 30 days as subsidiary to Furlough, whether on proceeding on Furlough or on return from Furlough. Leave granted as subsidiary to Furlough can only be spent in India.

XII.—During general leave an officer will be restricted to the pay of his grade,* and will forfeit all allowances, which will be paid to his locum tenens. If an officer exceeds the six months' leave admissible at one time under this Rule, the entire period will be converted into Furlough, and his allowances adjusted accordingly.

Privilege Leave.

XIII.—Subject to the exigencies of the service, Marine officers may be allowed 60 days' Privilege Leave during each year, and each leave may be taken in instalments.

XIV.—An officer who has Privilege Leave to his credit when proceeding on Leave or Furlough does not forfeit it, but Privilege Leave cannot be taken in continuation of Furlough, nor can Furlough be obtained in continuation of Privilege Leave. Privilege Leave may, however, be converted into general leave with the sanction of the Director of the Indian Marine, or into Furlough with the sanction of the Government of India.

XV—Privilege Leave will be granted by the Director of the Indian Marine, but it will be granted only on the understanding that no additional expense is thereby caused to the State either directly or indirectly, that the applicant's services can be spared, and that satisfactory arrangements for the performance of his duties during his absence can be made.

XVI.—Officers are at liberty to proceed wherever they may desire when on Privilege Leave, provided they can ensure their return before the expiration of the leave. If an officer exceeds his Privilege Leave, the whole period of his absence will be converted into general leave or Furlough, and his allowances and statement of service for Furlough adjusted accordingly.

Temporary Leave.

XVII.—Temporary Leave not exceeding 10 days, and not in anticipation or in extension of any kind of Leave or Furlough, may be granted by the Director and Deputy Director of the Indian Marine.

XVIII.—Temporary Leave not exceeding 72 hours may be granted by commanders of vessels and heads of departments to officers under their command.

General Regulations.

XIX.—It must be distinctly understood that Furlough or Leave cannot be claimed as a right. Both are subject to the exigencies of the public service, and will be granted only when an officer's services can be spared. Commanders of vessels and heads of departments will not forward an application for Furlough or Leave unless they are able to satisfy the Director of the Indian Marine that the officer's services can be spared without any inconvenience to the public service.

XX.—No grant of leave given under the conditions of these Rules will count against an officer's service for pension, and leave may be spent anywhere, i.e., within possible limits of return before it expires.

XXI.—Leave is reckoned from the day on which an officer avails himself of it, and it expires on the day he rejoins.

Furlough reckons from date of leaving India or from date of leaving his ship if at an outstation, unless specially stated by authority to commence on an earlier date; and in the event of an officer returning to India before the expiration of his Furlough, it ceases on the date of his return.

The day of return, whether from Leave or from Furlough, is a day of duty.

XXII.—Officers on Furlough will draw their pay from the India Office, but officers on General or Privilege Leave must arrange to draw their pay in India.

XXIII.—As a rule leave will be granted only during the period of the south-west monsoon.

XXIV.—Officers proceeding on Furlough will report their departure personally at the office of the Director or Deputy Director of the Indian Marine, except when they avail themselves of it at an outstation. An officer returning from Furlough or Leave will rejoin the ship to which he belongs; but if this impracticable, and he has not received instructions (which he should apply for beforehand), he will rejoin at

* This Rule will also hold good in the case of an officer holding a shore appointment, in which case the balance will be considered a staff allowance payable to the locum tenens, provided the latter does not thereby draw more than the pay of the appointment.
Bombay or Calcutta, reporting himself in person to the Director or Deputy Director. On the departure of an officer on Furlough or Leave, or on the return of an officer therefrom, the commander of the vessel will cause an entry to be made of the date in the ship's log book, and will forward an extract thereof by the next post to the Director.

XXV.—Officers arriving in Europe on Furlough or on General Leave* must report their arrival in writing to the Military Secretary at the India Office, and state their address; and for extension of Furlough or for permission to return to duty, they must also apply to the Military Secretary. †Before applying for extension of Furlough on private affairs they must obtain permission to do so from the Government of India, through the Director of Marine. The permission thus obtained must be attached to the application for extension, and submitted to the Military Secretary at the India Office.

Officers proceeding to the Colonies on Furlough should apply to India for extensions of Furlough and for permission to return to duty.

XXVI.—During the absence of an officer on Leave or Furlough, he must keep the Director of the Indian Marine acquainted with his actual address, and be prepared to return immediately to India, should his services be required. When on leave, such recall order will be issued by the Director; when on Furlough in Europe, by the Secretary of State. Officers spending their Furlough in Europe must keep the Secretary of State informed of their address.

XXVII.—Applications for Leave or Furlough must be made on the authorized form, which is obtainable from the Director or Deputy Director of the Indian Marine.

Note.—(Marine Circular No. 10 of 1885.)

The above Rules are applicable to—

I.—Officers on the Graded and Supernumerary List of Executive Officers.

II.—Officers on the Graded List of Engineers.

III.—Gazetted clerks.

IV.—Warrant officers who may be specially admitted to the Rules.

MARINE CIRCULAR OF THE GOVERNMENT OF INDIA, No. 7 of 1892.

With reference to Marine Circular No. 16 of the 1st November, 1884, the Governor-General in Council is pleased, under instructions from Her Majesty's Secretary of State for India, to publish the following revised Rules regarding the grant of leave to officers of the Royal Indian Marine.

2. These Rules shall apply to—

(a) All officers appointed to the Indian Marine after the date of their publication.

(b) Officers who may elect them within one year of the date of their publication.

Note.—The term "officers" includes the Graded and Supernumerary List of Executive Officers and the Graded List of Engineers.

3. Those who apply for leave of any kind within one year of the date of publication of these Rules must make their election when submitting their applications for leave; all others, whether on duty or on Furlough or leave on the date of publication of these Rules, may elect at convenience within the specified time.

4. All officers who elect these Rules will come under their provisions from the date of the receipt of their applications by the Government of India if they are in India, or at the India Office if they are at home; and they will be entitled to count all past Furlough and leave as service for pension under Rule V.

5. Those who elect these Rules while on Furlough or General Leave under the previous regulations will be allowed the option of continuing to draw any Furlough or leave allowances they may be in receipt of under those regulations, if more advantageous, until the expiry of such Furlough or General Leave or any extension thereof which would have been admissible under the previous regulations, subject to the limit of two years' absence from duty.

6. It must be clearly understood that officers who do not elect these Rules within the period stated will be held to have declined them, and will be allowed no further opportunity of electing them.

7. "General Leave" and "Subsidiary Leave" will not be granted to officers under these Rules.

Rules.

I. An officer subject to these Rules may be granted—

(a) Privilege Leave and Temporary Leave under such regulations as may from time to time be in force.

(b) Leave in or out of India for one year, capable of extension to two years' absence from duty under conditions stated below.

* Marine Circular No. 19 of 1888.
† Marine Circular No. 3 of 1889.
II. During leave in or out of India other than Privilege or Temporary Leave, the following rates of pay will be drawn whether an officer holds a shore appointment or not:

An officer promoted while on leave will be entitled to the higher rate of leave pay from date of promotion.

III. Leave may be granted at any time at the discretion of the Government of India, on the recommendation of the Director of the Royal Indian Marine.

IV. Extensions of leave in or out of India in excess of one year, but not exceeding two years' absence from duty in all, may be granted on medical certificate or on special or urgent grounds, at the discretion of the sanctioning authority. The previous assent of the Government of India will be required for extensions except on medical certificate, and must be obtained by the applicant through the Director of the Royal Indian Marine. Extensions beyond two years' absence from duty will only be admissible in very special cases, and without any pay whatever.

V. Leave in or out of India will reckon as service for pension.

VI. Leave will commence on the date of being struck off duty, except that in the case of an officer having to appear before a Medical Board the date of being struck off duty will mean the date on which he quits the station where he is examined and invalided. In cases of leave out of India on medical certificate the period of leave recommended by a Medical Board as necessary will be held to commence on the date of quitting India. In all cases, however, an officer will be due to rejoin his ship or appointment at the expiry of the period granted to him, the day on which he rejoins it being reckoned as a day of duty.

VII. An officer unable on account of ill-health to return to his duty within the maximum period of two years' absence will, unless specially granted leave without pay, be placed on temporary or permanent retirement, according to the circumstances of his case. An undue amount of leave on account of ill-health will likewise render an officer liable to be transferred to temporary or permanent retirement.

VIII. An officer on leave in or out of India will be required to rejoin his appointment at once on being recalled to duty on account of the exigencies of the service, unless pronounced by a Medical Board to be unfit to do so.

IX. An officer proceeding on leave will report his departure personally at the office of the Director or Deputy Director of the Royal Indian Marine, except when he avails himself of it at an out-station. Except when ordered to the contrary, all officers returning from leave will report themselves to the Director of the Royal Indian Marine at Bombay.

An officer arriving in Europe on leave must report his arrival in writing to the Military Secretary at the India Office, and state his address; and for extension of leave, or for permission to return to duty, he must also apply to the Military Secretary. An officer applying for extension of leave on private affairs must, except in very special or urgent circumstances, attach an intimation of the assent of the Government of India.

An officer proceeding to the Colonies on leave should apply to India for extensions of leave and for permission to return to duty.

X. Leave pay under these Rules, when issued out of India, will be converted into sterling at the official rate of exchange in force for the period when the pay becomes due, as fixed annually for the adjustment of financial transactions between the Indian and Imperial Governments.

XI. Advances not exceeding three months' full pay of grade, subject to a limit of £100 to Commanders, and £65 to officers of junior rank, will be allowed on proceeding on or returning from leave, and on returning from temporary retirement. Advances made in England will be recovered in India by monthly instalments of one-fourth of the pay drawn by the officers. Advances made in India will be noted on the last pay certificates of officers, and no issue of leave pay will be made till the sum advanced has accrued as such. In case of death no recovery of advances made under this rule is to be effected from the estate of the deceased officer.

XII. Marine officers not holding shore appointments of Rs. 1,000 per mensem will be eligible for the grant of non-regulation passages in troopships when such passages are available.
Privilege and Temporary Leave under these Rules.

XIII. Subject to the exigencies of the service, Marine officers may be allowed sixty days' Privilege Leave during each year, and such leave may be taken in instalments.

XIV. Accumulated Privilege Leave for ninety days may be granted to an officer who has no Privilege Leave during the preceding thirty-three months, but no "leave in or out of India," if exceeding six months, can be counted as part of the fixed thirty-three months.

XV. An officer who has Privilege Leave (ordinary or accumulated) at his credit, when proceeding on "leave in or out of India," does not forfeit it, but Privilege Leave cannot be taken in continuation of "leave in or out of India," nor can "leave in or out of India" be taken in continuation of Privilege Leave.

Privilege Leave may, however, be converted into "leave in or out of India," with the sanction of the Government of India.

XVI. An officer returning from accumulated Privilege Leave granted in one year and extending into the next is eligible for ordinary Privilege Leave during the period when such leave is available in the year in which he returns, provided he rejoins before proceeding on ordinary Privilege Leave.

XVII. Privilege Leave will be granted by the Director of the Royal Indian Marine, but only on the understanding that no additional expense is thereby caused to the State either directly or indirectly, that the applicant's services can be spared, and that satisfactory arrangements for the performance of his duties during his absence can be made.

XVIII. Privilege Leave (ordinary or accumulated) reckons as service for pension.

XIX. As a rule Privilege Leave will only be granted during the period of the south-west monsoon.

XX. Officers are at liberty to proceed wherever they may desire when on Privilege Leave, provided they can ensure their return before the expiration of the leave. If an officer exceeds his Privilege Leave the whole period of his absence will be converted into "leave in or out of India," and his allowances and statement of service for "leave in or out of India" adjusted accordingly.

XXI. Privilege Leave is reckoned from the day on which an officer avails himself of it, and it expires on the day he rejoins, the day of return being reckoned as a day of duty.

XXII. An officer of the floating establishment returning from Privilege Leave will, if possible, rejoin the ship to which he belongs, but if this is impracticable, and he has not received instructions (which he should apply for beforehand), he will rejoin at Bombay or Calcutta, reporting himself in person to the Director or Deputy-Director. On the departure of an officer on Privilege Leave or on the return of an officer therefrom, the Commander of the vessel will cause an entry to be made in the ship's log, and will forward an extract thereof by the next post to the Director.

XXIII. Temporary leave not exceeding ten days and not in anticipation or in extension of any other kind of leave may be granted by the Director and Deputy-Director of the Royal Indian Marine.

XXIV. Temporary leave not exceeding seventy-two hours may be granted by Commanders of vessels and heads of departments to officers under their command.

General Regulations.

XXV. It must be distinctly understood that leave in or out of India or Privilege Leave cannot be claimed as a right. Both are subject to the exigencies of the public service, and will be granted only when an officer's services can be spared. Commanders of vessels and heads of departments will not forward an application for Privilege or other Leave unless they are able to satisfy the Director of the Royal Indian Marine that the officer's services can be spared without any inconvenience to the public service.

XXVI. An officer who has not completed his term of probation for the Marine service cannot be granted leave with retention of his probationary appointment in excess of three months.

XXVII. The name of an officer, granted leave out of India (other than Privilege Leave), will be removed from the ship on which borne, and he will draw his pay during such leave—

(a) if proceeded to Europe, through the India Office,

(b) if proceeded to any colony named in the list in appendix No. 17 of the Civil Service Regulations, in such colony

He can, however, draw his leave pay in India if he prefers it.

XXVIII. The name of an officer, granted leave in India (other than Privilege Leave), will be removed from the ship on which borne, and he will draw his pay during such time from any treasury in India in communication with the Examiner of Marine Accounts.

XXIX. The name of an officer granted Privilege Leave (ordinary or accumulated), will continue on the books of his ship, and he will draw his pay either from the ship or from any treasury in India or through a bank or agent, as may be arranged through the Examiner of Marine Accounts.

XXX. During the absence of an officer on leave (privilege or otherwise), he must keep the Director of the Royal Indian Marine acquainted with his actual address, and be prepared to return immediately to India, should his services be required. When on Privilege Leave, such recall order will be issued by the Director; when on leave in Europe (other than privilege), by the Secretary of State. Officers spending their leave (other than privilege) in Europe must keep the Secretary of State informed of their address.

XXXI. The Secretary of State in Council reserves to himself the right of making any change in the foregoing Rules which circumstances may require.

**PENSION REGULATIONS OF THE INDIAN MARINE.**

**MARINE CIRCULARS OF THE GOVERNMENT OF INDIA, Nos. 13 OF 1885 and 14 of 1887.**

1. The following is the scale of pensions and compassionate allowances admissible to officers and engineers of Her Majesty's Indian Marine and to their families.

2. The service for pension of an officer of the Marine reckons from date of joining his ship or appointment if he is 19 years of age or over; otherwise from date of attaining that age.

3. An officer admitted to the service after 25 years of age will be subject to reduction of pension in the manner and under the rules laid down in the Civil Pension Code.

4. Retirement at the age of 55 years will be compulsory, and all officers and engineers of that age now in the service, as well as those who may attain that age within one year, will be required to retire at the expiration of one year from the date of this order.* Should an officer holding the appointment of Director or Deputy-Director of the Indian Marine attain that age during his incumbency, he may, with the approval of the Government of India, complete five years in the appointment.

*This rule will not be applicable to those officers who have already received a special extension of tenure.

5. The following is the scale of pensions:

The periods of service mentioned in the foregoing table are inclusive of the periods of Furlough allowed to count towards pension.

6. The following extra pension will be granted to an officer of the Indian Marine retiring after five years' service as Deputy Director or Director:

| Service Description                                                                 | Per annum |
|------------------------------------------------------------------------------------|-----------|
| For five years' continuous service as Director                                    | Rs. 2,000 |

7. Service in the survey, or in port or dockyard appointments, gives no claim to any higher position than that fixed for an officer's rank in the Marine. Officers not on the Marine list now serving in such appointments will remain under their present Rules.

8. The pensions of warrant officers, gunners, and clerks will be calculated under the Rules for the Uncovenanted Service, as laid down in the Civil Pension Code, Rs. 60 per mensem (compensation in lieu of board and lodging) being added to their pay for the calculation of pension.

9. Pensions will be payable in rupees in India. If paid in England, they will be converted at the rate of exchange fixed yearly for the adjustment of financial transactions between the Imperial and Indian Governments subject to a minimum rate of 1s. 9d. the rupee.

10. An officer may be allowed to commute a portion, not exceeding one-third of his pension, the commuted value being payable in India under the Rules in clause 23, India Army Circulars, of 1884.

11. Compassionate allowance on the following scale will be granted to the families of officers who may be drowned or meet with a violent death in the execution of duty:

The cases of the families of the Director or Deputy Director will be specially considered.

12. The regulations and conditions under which all such compassionate allowances are to be awarded will be analogous to those prescribed for the military service.

Officers are required to signify their intention to accept the above pension Rules by the 31st December, 1885, otherwise it will be understood that they have decided to remain under the Rules now applicable to them.

TEMPORARY RETIREMENT—INDIAN MARINE.

(Marine Circular, No. 15 of 1887.)

1. Officers of the Indian Marine, who after exhausting the Furlough admissible to them under the Rules printed on p. xciv. are unfit for service, but not irremediably broken in health, may be temporarily transferred to the Retired List.

2. An officer granted temporary retirement will be permitted to remain in that position until his total continuous absence from duty, on Furlough and temporary retirement together, amounts to four years. If then still unfit to return to duty, he must be placed on the Permanent Retired List, receiving the pension, if any, or gratuity for which he had qualified at the time of being granted temporary retirement.

3. Time spent on temporary retirement will not count as service for pension, nor will an officer be eligible for promotion while he is in that position. An officer placed on the effective list from temporary retirement will be restored to the grade, and numerical position in that grade, which he occupied before his retirement.

4. Officers will be required to appear before a Medical Board at the expiration of one year on temporary retirement, and again, if retained in that position, before the end of the second year; on doing so they will be allowed their bona fide travelling expenses, and lodging allowance at 3s. per diem, according to rank. In case of appearing before a Board at other times than those specified, at their own request, they must do so at their own expense.

5. Temporary retirement will be subject to the condition that the disease which necessitates it must have been contracted in and by the service; and it will also be subject to Rule 3 of the Pension Regulations of the Indian Marine (p. xcvi.).
INDIAN MILITARY SERVICE FAMILY PENSION REGULATIONS.

(Instituted 1st Jan., 1873.)

REGULATIONS FOR THE PROVISION OF PENSIONS FOR THE WIDOWS AND ORPHANS OF MILITARY AND MEDICAL AND ECCLESIASTICAL OFFICERS IN THE SERVICE OF THE GOVERNMENT OF INDIA.

1. Pensions will be provided under these regulations for the widows and orphans of the following officers on the Indian Establishment, not being entitled to the benefits of any of the late Military and Medical Funds:

- Officers of the Staff Corps.
- Officers of the Indian Medical Department.
- Continuous service officers* of Royal Artillery and Engineers.
- Chaplains (including Probationary Chaplains).
- Officers of the Royal Indian Marine (under special rules).

3. Every officer who enters the service on and after the 1st January, 1873, must, as a condition of his appointment, provide pensions for his family under these regulations.

5. For the purpose of these regulations officers are classed as follows:

Class I.—Lieutenant-Colonels in receipt of Colonel's allowances, and Surgeons-Major-General.

II.—Lieutenant-Colonels, Archdeacons, Surgeon-Colonels, Brigade-Surgeon-Lieut.-Colonels and Surgeon-Lieut.-Colonels.

III.—Majors, Senior Chaplains, Surgeons-Major, and 1st Grade Commanders R.I. Marine.

IV.—Captains, Junior Chaplains, and Surgeon-Captains who have served the Government of India for more than six years, 2nd and 3rd Grade Commanders, and Chief Engineers R.I. Marine.

V.—Lieutenants and Medical Officers who have served the Government of India for less than six years, also Lieutenants and Sub-Lieutenants, Engineers and Assistant-Engineers of the R.I. Marine.

6. The pensions provided under these regulations are payable monthly in India, and quarterly in arrear in England, and to date of death.

7. The amounts of the pensions provided are as follows, in addition to any pensions or compassionate allowances granted under Royal Warrant.

(N.B.—The one now in force is dated 2nd April, 1894.)

8. The pension of a minor orphan will be paid to his or her mother, or other duly appointed or recognized guardian.

Note.—Annuitants in India may either receive their pensions in Indian currency at the official rate of exchange or in England in sterling, but having once exercised the option, any subsequent change can only be permitted at the commencement of the official year.

Contributions.

9. The contributions for pensions under these regulations, and the pensions of widows, will be regulated by the class of the contributing officer. An officer cannot secure a higher pension for his widow by contributing as if he belonged to a higher class.*

* As an exception to this rule, an officer who has completed five years' service as a substantive Lieutenant-Colonel has the option of subscribing in Class I. (A.C. 34, of January, 1881.)
10. Contributions will be deducted by paymasters or other disbursing officers from the pay abstracts of officers contributing.

10A. The circumstance that an officer is not in receipt of pay does not relieve him from the necessity of paying his contributions.

11. Donations may be paid in one sum, or in 12 equal monthly instalments. If a donation be paid in instalments, interest on the unpaid portion will be levied at the rate of 4½ per cent. per annum. The balance of any contribution due at an officer's death will be recovered ratably, without interest, from the pensions of his widow and orphans, in 12 monthly instalments in India, or four quarterly instalments in England.

11A. Contributions which become due from subscribers when in Europe must be paid in England in sterling. If a subscriber, previous to quitting India, has commenced the payment of any donation by instalments, he may either complete the payment of the donation in India before leaving, or pay the remaining instalments in England at English rates; but an officer on half-pay who continues to subscribe at Indian rates has the option of paying in India.

**Arrears.**

13. Interest at the rate of 4½ per cent. per annum will be charged on arrears. Donations will become due from the date on which the liability is incurred, viz., on marriage, on promotion, or on the birth of a child, but interest will not be charged on sums paid within one month from the date on which they become due.

**Reports of Marriages, Births, and Deaths.**

14. An officer who is married at the date of his admission into the service must report the fact of his marriage at the time, and the names and dates of birth of his children, if any have been born to him. An officer in the service must report his marriage, or the birth of a child born in wedlock, or the death of a wife or child, within one month of the occurrence, to the Comptroller of Military Accounts in the Presidency, or the Director of Funds, India Office, when an officer is in Europe. Forms for this purpose are given in the Appendix.

15. The birth of every child born alive must be reported; but if a child die before it is thirty days old no payment in respect of it will be required.

15a. If the report of a marriage, or of the birth of a child, be not made within one month of the occurrence, the donation payable in each case will be increased 2½ per cent., and the interest thereon charged from the date of marriage or birth of the child. After six months' delay donations will be increased 5 per cent., and interest charged in the usual manner. (G.O.G.G. No. 138 of 1887.)

15b. In the event of the report of a marriage or the birth of a child not being made by a subscriber during his lifetime, in accordance with the Rules, the widow or child will not be entitled to any benefits. (Army Circulars, India, 1880, Clause II.)

**Posthumous Child.**

16. A pension will be granted to a posthumous child on payment of the donation prescribed in Table V., which may be recovered by 12 monthly instalments in India, or four quarterly instalments in England. The report of the birth of a posthumous child must be made in Form D., the last sentence being omitted.

**Commutation of Contributions.**

17. Officers may at the date of retirement, or at any subsequent period, commute their monthly contribution by a single payment representing the value thereof during the joint lives of husband and wife, and father and child.

In the event of the wife dying after the date of commutation, contribution at the unmarried rate must be resumed, or, as an alternative, it may be commuted.

A subscriber who has commuted will on re-marrying become liable for marriage donation and the difference between the married and unmarried rates of contribution, or the commuted value on the joint lives.
18. Widowers and bachelors may in like manner commute their monthly contribution for life. On each subsequent marriage they will become liable for the donation and difference of contribution laid down in the previous articles.

Donation and contribution or its commuted value must be paid for all children born to a subscriber after his retirement from the service.

Deviation of Pensions.

19. If a widow re-marry, her pension will cease during coverture, but if she again become a widow she will be entitled to revert to her pension as widow of her first husband, or, if her last husband have been a contributor, to receive a pension at her option as the widow of her last husband. A widow can only receive one pension.

20. The pension of a male orphan is payable until he attains the age of 21 years.

20a. Subscribers can make special provision for pension to sons who may become permanently incapacitated from earning a livelihood.

The pensions so provided for will commence at the age of 21, if the son be then fatherless, or, after that age, on his becoming fatherless, and as regards the amounts of such pensions, and the subscriptions to be paid to secure them, each case will be considered and determined on its merits.

21. The mother or guardian of a male orphan who has completed the age of 16 may, at any time thereafter (on application in Forms F to H annexed to these regulations), have the residue of his pension commuted into a single payment, for the due application of which the mother or guardian will be held responsible. The following table gives the commuted values of such pensions:

| Years | 16 | 17 | 18 | 19 | 20 |
|-------|----|----|----|----|----|
| Months | £   | £   | £   | £   | £   |
| 0     | 129 | 106 | 81  | 56  | 28  |
| 3     | 123 | 100 | 75  | 49  | 21  |
| 6     | 117 | 94  | 68  | 42  | 14  |
| 9     | 111 | 87  | 62  | 35  | 7   |

22. The pension of a female orphan continues until her marriage, and then ceases absolutely. It does not revive on widowhood.

Good Conduct.

23. The pensions provided under these regulations shall, in all cases, be held during good behaviour only, and will be withheld if any pensioner is found to be leading an immoral life, or on proof of any gross misconduct. The order of the Secretary of State for India in Council in any such case shall be final and conclusive.

Alienation of Pension.

24. A pension paid under these regulations may not be transferred or assigned, or in any way alienated, from the pensioner to whom or for whose benefit it is payable.

Passage Money.

25. An officer may, by a special contribution, provide passage money from India for his widow and orphans. The amount so secured will belong to the officer's estate, but will be primarily applicable to the provision of passage money and outfit for any member or members of his family (wife and children) who may be in India at the time of his death. If the whole amount is not required for the above purpose the balance will be paid over to the officer's estate. The amount secured must not exceed 1,500 rupees, and a health certificate must in every case be furnished by the subscriber. The value will be determined by the Tables in Major-General Hannington's report.

25a. The special contribution can be paid by monthly instalments not exceeding 24, the instalments in arrear bearing interest at 4½ per cent. per annum, and in the event of a subscriber dying before completion of the payment, the balance due at his death will be deducted from the sum insured.

25b. Native commissioned medical officers are required to pay, as in the case of their ordinary contributions, 5 per cent. over and above the ordinary rates of special contribution (Army Circulars India, 1884, Clause 33).

25c. In the event of a subscriber's family not having occasion to make use of the passage money for which special contribution has been made, it will be paid to his estate on his death, irrespective of whether this occurs before or after his retirement, or whether he continued to subscribe to the pension branch up to the date of his death.

If an officer on retirement desires to sever his connection with the Insurance Branch, he will be allowed the option of receiving the value of the sum assured at the date of withdrawal.

If, however, the option is declined at the date of withdrawal from the pension Branch, the sum originally assured will be paid in accordance with the Rules at the decease of the subscriber.

(A.C.I. 1886. Cl. 85.)

Transfer to Her Majesty's Line Regiments, and Officers who resign.

26. Officers who may be transferred from the Indian Staff Corps to Her Majesty's Line regiments, and officers who resign the Service, will be entitled to receive back such portion of their contributions as may be in excess of the risk borne during their membership, but they cannot continue subscribers.
Half-Pay.

27. A Married officer on half-pay must continue to subscribe at Indian rates (which can be paid in India) for full benefits, or at lower rates for reduced benefits. In the event of his return to full pay, he will revert to full rates and benefits. Unmarried officers must continue to subscribe at the Europe rate of subscription.

Retired Officers.

28. Married officers who retire from the service on a pension may continue to subscribe at the Europe rate of subscription, or they may withdraw, receiving back such portion of their contributions as is in excess of the risk borne during the term of their membership; but the usual subscription will be deducted from the pension of all such officers until they shall have intimated in writing their intention of withdrawing. Unmarried officers may continue their subscription on the same terms as married officers, but will not be entitled on retirement to any refund in the event of their withdrawal.

Dismissed Officers.

29. An officer who is dismissed the service by sentence of a court-martial, or by other competent authority, will cease, ipso facto, to be a contributor under these regulations, and will have no claim to any refund. His family will not be entitled to any pensions under these regulations.

Certificates.

30. Declarations as to continued widowhood and the survival of children must be furnished to the Accountant-General, India Office, by whom pensions in Europe are paid under the authority of the Director of Funds.

Note A.—The contributions and donations to be paid by Native Members of the Covenanted Medical Service are fixed for the present at an increase of 5 per cent. on the rates paid by Europeans.

APPENDIX.

Note.—In England all reports and applications for pensions must be made to the Director of Funds, India Office, London, S.W.

For the present, the rate of interest is fixed at 4½ per cent. per annum, and the rate of exchange with England at 1s. 8d. the rupee.
